update.description:
* enable MATLAB building on Linux
 * find `mex` instead of just `mex.bat`
 * customize `mex` args for Linux vs. Windows
 * put Octave and MATLAB .mex files into separate directories (both build and install)
 * add custom `mexopts.sh` file to allow customization of compiler flags

This works for me on Trusty, at least as far as running `hx_matlab_controller.m`.

I haven't tried it on Windows, but I don't think that I've broken that support (except maybe for the change of .mex install location; I'm not sure how the SDK gets produced).

Note: I first was getting this error:

~~~~
>> hx_read_sensors
Invalid MEX-file '/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/matlab/hxgz.mexa64':
/usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/bin/glnxa64/../../sys/os/glnxa64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.19' not found (required by
/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libhaptix-comm.so.0)

Error in hx_read_sensors (line 27)
  sensor = hxgz('read_sensors');
~~~~

The issue seems to be caused by the copy of `libstdc++.so` that ships with MATLAB.  After finding it recommended for working around similar problems with other tools (e.g., openoffice), I did the following:

~~~~
cd /usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/sys/os/glnxa64
sudo mv libstdc++.so.6 libstdc++.so.6.orig
~~~~

Effectively, that hides MATLAB's own c++ lib, which makes it use the system-installed one, which doesn't have the dependency problem.

This issue might be related to the fact that I'm building with gcc-4.8 (default on Trusty), and MATLAB only officially supports up through gcc-4.7 (you get a warning while building). Then again, I installed gcc-4.7 and built the .mex with it, and still got the same result.
update.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

content.raw: It looks like @_jriviero already did the SDK generation part in [release-tools](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/haptix/job/haptix_comm-sdk_any-builder-windows7-amd64/2/), and we don't need to change the docs because the files are copied to a folder called `matlab` in SDK generation anyway.
content.html: It looks like @_jriviero already did the SDK generation part in release-tools, and we don't need to change the docs because the files are copied to a folder called matlab in SDK generation anyway.

pull_request.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

pullrequest.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

content.raw: I'm testing this for backwards compatibility on Windows right now. Carlos had told me that the `.m` files, the Matlab example and the `.mex` end up in `build\install\Debug\lib\haptix-comm\mex`, but on this branch they end up in `build\install\Debug\lib\haptix-comm\matlab`. Will we need to change documentation and the SDK generation process to reflect this?
content.html: I'm testing this for backwards compatibility on Windows right now. Carlos had told me that the .m files, the Matlab example and the .mex end up in build\install\Debug\lib\haptix-comm\mex, but on this branch they end up in build\install\Debug\lib\haptix-comm\matlab. Will we need to change documentation and the SDK generation process to reflect this?

pullrequest.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

content.raw:
Out of curiosity: instead of modifying the libstdc++ file, what about using:

`LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6 matlab`
content.html:
Out of curiosity: instead of modifying the libstdc++ file, what about using:

LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6 matlab

pull_request.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

pullrequest.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

content.raw: We will need to merge [sdk pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-request/72/move-matlab-file-directory/diff) to keep things working after merging this PR.
content.html: We will need to merge sdk pull request to keep things working after merging this PR.

pull_request.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

pullrequest.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

content.raw: Btw, the `mexopts.sh` file is just a copy of what comes with MATLAB, with the `CFLAGS` setting changed to use `-std=c99`, which is needed to parse `//`-style comments.
content.html: Btw, the mexopts.sh file is just a copy of what comes with MATLAB, with the CFLAGS setting changed to use -std=c99, which is needed to parse //-style comments.

pull_request.title: Add support for building MATLAB .mex on Linux (#11)

update.description:
* enable MATLAB building on Linux
 * find `mex` instead of just `mex.bat`
 * customize `mex` args for Linux vs. Windows
 * put Octave and MATLAB .mex files into separate directories (both build and install)
 * add custom `mexopts.sh` file to allow customization of compiler flags

This works for me on Trusty, at least as far as running `hx_matlab_controller.m`.

I haven't tried it on Windows, but I don't think that I've broken that support (except maybe for the change of .mex install location; I'm not sure how the SDK gets produced).

Note: I first was getting this error:

~~~~
>> hx_read_sensors
Invalid MEX-file '/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/matlab/hxgz.mexa64':
/usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/bin/glnxa64/../../sys/os/glnxa64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.19' not found (required by
/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libhaptix-comm.so.0)

Error in hx_read_sensors (line 27)
  sensor = hxgz('read_sensors');
~~~~

The issue seems to be caused by the copy of `libstdc++.so` that ships with MATLAB.  After finding it recommended for working around similar problems with other tools (e.g., openoffice), I did the following:

~~~~
cd /usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/sys/os/glnxa64
sudo mv libstdc++.so.6 libstdc++.so.6.orig
~~~~

Effectively, that hides MATLAB's own c++ lib, which makes it use the system-installed one, which doesn't have the dependency problem.

This issue might be related to the fact that I'm building with gcc-4.8 (default on Trusty), and MATLAB only officially supports up through gcc-4.7 (you get a warning while building). Then again, I installed gcc-4.7 and built the .mex with it, and still got the same result.
